head.supplied: See fn 3: There are many notes like this, that make the fn 1 note ‘letter not found’ seem a bit odd. I have assumed that the cross reference is to another register entry, rather than to a complete let...

p.style: font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; color: #0000FF; hyphenate: false; break-before: page;

div.p:
or reel 5? check at PRO.
Letter not found; item is a register entry only, of an item dated 18 July 1860. See fn 3: There are many notes like this, that make the fn 1 note ‘letter not found’ seem a bit odd. I have assumed that the cross reference is to another register entry, rather than to a complete letter, but it strikes me now that if that was the case, then the note would/should have said so, So, whose letter / memo is in VPRS 226/P1, PROV?

p.style: font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; hyphenate: false; color: #C00000;

div.p: It strikes me now (2024-01-18) that this might be a paraphrase of, perhaps, the folder cover
No. 4155, unit 5, VPRS 227/P1 inward correspondence register, VA 538 Department of Crown Lands and Survey, Public Record Office, Victoria.

[Walk, Royal Socy Ground]
check that this is the text from the register. M requested permission to form a Walk through the ground of the Royal Society using quarry pebbles (VPRS 226/P1, PROV).
We have no reord of such a request.It seems as if there should be at least a blind entry for that request. Or
